body:
I don't agree. The founders were strong christians and they were so involved in politics they lead a rebellion against a tyrannical government and still remained strong christians. One of the reasons we are in the situation we are in now is because christians avoid politics far more than they should. Is our kingdom in heaven? Yes! But AFTER our time here on earth, and what kind of love do we show to allow the worlds children and future generations to suffer under communism and tyranny? A christian United States got involved in WW1 and WW2. If the cause is just, then christians should be there because our God is a god of truth, justice and even scales. We should hate wickedness, evil and sin. We should hate that certain people in our government are creating a wedge between a cohesive nation AND between the nation and Christ.

I can't get behind this, especially now when people are very vocal about their desire to reprogram citizens, take their children and place them in camps, with all seriousness. As christian men it is of great import that we protect our families, and that means being in the know and making wise decisions.

body: For every war we have been in I can find people who think we were in it "for the wrong reason". Thanks, but that's not the subject at hand. Christians need to be involved in politics steeped in prayer and biblical wisdom, likely now more than ever. We shouldn't replace God with politics, but God should be woven throughout our political involvement. Lack of this has lead to where we are now.

body:
This is why you must be involved and informed:

https://www.dhs.gov/news/2021/01/27/dhs-issues-national-terrorism-advisory-system-ntas-bulletin

It won't be long before being known as a christian may land you on that list, or carrying your bible, or going to a bible study, or having references to scripture on your car window. The people pushing this are in a minority and they are betting on the laziness of the West to allow them to carry out their schemes. It's not just YOUR life and livelihood at stake, its your neighbors, your childrens, your childrens children. There may come a time to stand down as martyrs, but now is not that time. Jesus told his disciples to sell their cloak and buy a sword. A PHYSICAL SWORD. A WEAPON. And the last time I checked there was no scripture instructing us to put those down until He returns with a sword of his own. We may not be called to attack, but we are surely called upon to protect those in our care.

body:
"Render unto Caesar that which is Caesar's but render unto God that which is God's."

Meaning that God rules the spirit but men rule the land. It is wrong to ignore the rule of the land and expect God to take care of what he specifically placed in our domain.

body: I unfortunately lost my brother to the Jehovah Witness protection program. I have long mocked those people for being totally divorced from politics to the point they neither vote nor pay taxes they cannot evade. After the Republic gasped its death rattle with this stolen election, I have reconsidered the Witness avoidance of all things civic.

body: Someone's entire life shouldn't be political. To replace entertainment with political hatred/negativity on one side or the other will, most likely, cause a person to hate those they disagree with because everyone else they agree with hates those same people. Of course, we need to have an impact on politics, but we must set aside time for it in a day, and not let it overcome our life. If we let politics overcome our life and identity, we will become more focused on being right on our political spectrum than being right with God.

body: Nonsense! If the rule is just, then yes, but you think God desires that men live under oppression? The Jews called out because of the harsh treatment by pharaoh and God sent Moses! God detests wickedness, even in governments. Oppression may be used by God for his purpose, but that men should want to live free of oppression is not frowned upon by God simply because the oppression is at the hand of the rulers of a land. The creation of our nation is stark proof of that. We were even an entire ocean away from England and God's presence was still woven throughout the revolution! If it is wrong to expect God to be present in "our domain" then why pray for healing? For deliverance from evil or poverty? God says if we call upon him he will hear us and that our fervent prayers have value and effect. God cares much about the things we care about including our own freedom and safety. It is our job to ensure our freedom and safety, but God does not leave us alone in such endeavors.

parent.body:
I don't agree. The founders were strong christians and they were so involved in politics they lead a rebellion against a tyrannical government and still remained strong christians. One of the reasons we are in the situation we are in now is because christians avoid politics far more than they should. Is our kingdom in heaven? Yes! But AFTER our time here on earth, and what kind of love do we show to allow the worlds children and future generations to suffer under communism and tyranny? A christian United States got involved in WW1 and WW2. If the cause is just, then christians should be there because our God is a god of truth, justice and even scales. We should hate wickedness, evil and sin. We should hate that certain people in our government are creating a wedge between a cohesive nation AND between the nation and Christ.

I can't get behind this, especially now when people are very vocal about their desire to reprogram citizens, take their children and place them in camps, with all seriousness. As christian men it is of great import that we protect our families, and that means being in the know and making wise decisions.

body:
Also nonsense. Am I to make it clear that I love a man I see stabbing others on the street? I may feel saddened that something in his life caused him to do this but I hate him for harming others and should give no quarter in doing whatever is necessary to stop him, even ending his life then and there, without question or concern. God told the Israelites to kill every man, woman and child of more than one opposing nation. Did he tell them to make sure they knew they were loved first? They were wicked people doing wicked things and God had them destroyed because of it using His people. I'm all for loving our enemies, but I seriously doubt this applies to someone who is attempting to enslave or kill you. I see no evidence of it in scripture beyond Christ, who did it to fulfill his purpose. If he had intended for us to do the same then why instruct the disciples to literally sell their clothes for a weapon?

I may pray that "our rulers" turn from wickedness and rule with wisdom, but the moment they promote wickedness and come after me and mine I hate them and will do what must be done to prevent those God has placed in my charge from harm. God hates these people!

Psalms 11:5
The Lord tests the righteous and the wicked,
*And the one who loves violence His soul hates.*

Hosea 9:15
All their wickedness is in Gilgal: *for there I hated them: for the wickedness of their doings I will drive them out of mine house, I will love them no more*: all their princes are revolters.

body:
I agree. The "Wait here. Jesus is coming back to save us" ethic is a trick to instill passivity and compliance. I don't have an organized religion myself, but from what I've learned, Jesus and his disciples were not passive or compliant in the face of oppression and evil by the state. They worked every day to expose it and to show a better way and spoke against the rulers of the day even when it meant death or ostracism. I don't believe they would be standing by and staying silent during this insane global authoritarian power grab. 

That said, mainstream left/right politics is also a trap used to divide us so we're less effective in exposing and stopping this evil. 

I think to be Christian means to take on the political as personal - live your ethics, values, and personal politics every day, but that has to include both actively resisting what is wrong and what is evil and nurturing and protecting what is right and good.
body_html:
I agree. The "Wait here. Jesus is coming back to save us" ethic is a trick to instill passivity and compliance. I don't have an organized religion myself, but from what I've learned, Jesus and his disciples were not passive or compliant in the face of oppression and evil by the state. They worked every day to expose it and to show a better way and spoke against the rulers of the day even when it meant death or ostracism. I don't believe they would be standing by and staying silent during this insane global authoritarian power grab.

That said, mainstream left/right politics is also a trap used to divide us so we're less effective in exposing and stopping this evil.

I think to be Christian means to take on the political as personal - live your ethics, values, and personal politics every day, but that has to include both actively resisting what is wrong and what is evil and nurturing and protecting what is right and good.

body: I can mostly agree with that, though I think Jesus particularly avoided politics because his purpose was not political but spiritual. He had a goal and it wasn't overthrowing Rome, it was overthrowing Death. That being said it is of great importance that, yes, we live our lives showing others the love of Christ (ethics, if we cant to call it) because really that, above all else, draws people in. You can preach a thousand sermons of hellfire against the unsaved and I promise not a one will be more effective than christians living a life of example. Many people get offended when you speak the word of God at them, but when they come and ask out of genuine curiosity or desperation they will soak it up and, most of the time, at least think about what you have said. We should always stand up for what is right and good and just and fair because these things are the things God loves, they are the order He has created. Anything against those things is of satan.

I don't have an organized religion myself, but from what I've learned, Jesus and his disciples were not passive or compliant in the face of oppression and evil by the state. They worked every day to expose it and to show a better way and spoke against the rulers of the day even when it meant death or ostracism. I don't believe they would be standing by and staying silent during this insane global authoritarian power grab. 

That said, mainstream left/right politics is also a trap used to divide us so we're less effective in exposing and stopping this evil. 

I think to be Christian means to take on the political as personal - live your ethics, values, and personal politics every day, but that has to include both actively resisting what is wrong and what is evil and nurturing and protecting what is right and good.

body:
The point to me is that the spiritual IS "political" when you get right down to it. I don't separate my spirituality and my sociopolitical efforts. They're one and the same.

Is exposing evil and corruption within the state a political act, or is it spiritual? I would say it's both.

parent.body: I can mostly agree with that, though I think Jesus particularly avoided politics because his purpose was not political but spiritual. He had a goal and it wasn't overthrowing Rome, it was overthrowing Death. That being said it is of great importance that, yes, we live our lives showing others the love of Christ (ethics, if we cant to call it) because really that, above all else, draws people in. You can preach a thousand sermons of hellfire against the unsaved and I promise not a one will be more effective than christians living a life of example. Many people get offended when you speak the word of God at them, but when they come and ask out of genuine curiosity or desperation they will soak it up and, most of the time, at least think about what you have said. We should always stand up for what is right and good and just and fair because these things are the things God loves, they are the order He has created. Anything against those things is of satan.

body: I actually find that issue interesting, as God is love, and if he is love, how can he hate? The answer that I have arrived at is "Perfect Hate," or otherwise not the same type of hate we're speaking about. To hate is to feel passionate dislike, and, unlike hate us humans feel, God can have a balance of dislike and love for someone without unjustly/hypocritically hating them, or will for someone to change while loving them all the same. However, we cannot have this balance of love and hate before it turns into the type of hypocritical judging that Jesus warned against in Matthew 7:1-2. God is never unjust, therefore he may judge, love, and "hate."

parent.body:
Also nonsense. Am I to make it clear that I love a man I see stabbing others on the street? I may feel saddened that something in his life caused him to do this but I hate him for harming others and should give no quarter in doing whatever is necessary to stop him, even ending his life then and there, without question or concern. God told the Israelites to kill every man, woman and child of more than one opposing nation. Did he tell them to make sure they knew they were loved first? They were wicked people doing wicked things and God had them destroyed because of it using His people. I'm all for loving our enemies, but I seriously doubt this applies to someone who is attempting to enslave or kill you. I see no evidence of it in scripture beyond Christ, who did it to fulfill his purpose. If he had intended for us to do the same then why instruct the disciples to literally sell their clothes for a weapon?

I may pray that "our rulers" turn from wickedness and rule with wisdom, but the moment they promote wickedness and come after me and mine I hate them and will do what must be done to prevent those God has placed in my charge from harm. God hates these people!

Psalms 11:5
The Lord tests the righteous and the wicked,
*And the one who loves violence His soul hates.*

Hosea 9:15
All their wickedness is in Gilgal: *for there I hated them: for the wickedness of their doings I will drive them out of mine house, I will love them no more*: all their princes are revolters.

body:
Psalm 139:

19 Oh that you would slay the wicked, O God!
    O men of blood, depart from me!
20 They speak against you with malicious intent;
    your enemies take your name in vain.
21 **Do I not hate those who hate you, O Lord?
    And do I not loathe those who rise up against you?**
22 **I hate them with complete hatred;
    I count them my enemies.**

We should hate what God hates, and he tells us what he hates through scripture, and to hate those things is not sin.

body:
We may "hate," but in the fashion mentioned prior. We cannot be neutral to evil, and we must dislike it, but we cannot allow ourselves to slide into the hate that causes us to hypocritically/unjustly judge. 

The verse is followed up with "God, search me; expose my wrong attitudes; deal with the idols in my heart; expose and eradicate what is dishonoring to you from my life." To hate with the wrong attitude is not something that should be desired. These verses are not disconnected but intertwined.

body: The world itself is fucking awful. Nothing is fair and most people are doomed to misery their entire lives even if they do everything right. Better politics will make it slightly more tolerable but really it always still comes down to pure luck, and to be honest it's silly to think we're going to stop it and I think it's the wrong hill to die on (especially when God himself allows whatever happens to happen, and we are powerless unlike we want to think). The nihilists are right, there is absolutely no meaning or purpose at all in this world, it just is, read Ecclesiastes. It was never about this world and if it is that's a sign something's not right.

parent.body:
I don't agree. The founders were strong christians and they were so involved in politics they lead a rebellion against a tyrannical government and still remained strong christians. One of the reasons we are in the situation we are in now is because christians avoid politics far more than they should. Is our kingdom in heaven? Yes! But AFTER our time here on earth, and what kind of love do we show to allow the worlds children and future generations to suffer under communism and tyranny? A christian United States got involved in WW1 and WW2. If the cause is just, then christians should be there because our God is a god of truth, justice and even scales. We should hate wickedness, evil and sin. We should hate that certain people in our government are creating a wedge between a cohesive nation AND between the nation and Christ.

I can't get behind this, especially now when people are very vocal about their desire to reprogram citizens, take their children and place them in camps, with all seriousness. As christian men it is of great import that we protect our families, and that means being in the know and making wise decisions.

parent.body:
Also nonsense. Am I to make it clear that I love a man I see stabbing others on the street? I may feel saddened that something in his life caused him to do this but I hate him for harming others and should give no quarter in doing whatever is necessary to stop him, even ending his life then and there, without question or concern. God told the Israelites to kill every man, woman and child of more than one opposing nation. Did he tell them to make sure they knew they were loved first? They were wicked people doing wicked things and God had them destroyed because of it using His people. I'm all for loving our enemies, but I seriously doubt this applies to someone who is attempting to enslave or kill you. I see no evidence of it in scripture beyond Christ, who did it to fulfill his purpose. If he had intended for us to do the same then why instruct the disciples to literally sell their clothes for a weapon?

I may pray that "our rulers" turn from wickedness and rule with wisdom, but the moment they promote wickedness and come after me and mine I hate them and will do what must be done to prevent those God has placed in my charge from harm. God hates these people!

Psalms 11:5
The Lord tests the righteous and the wicked,
*And the one who loves violence His soul hates.*

Hosea 9:15
All their wickedness is in Gilgal: *for there I hated them: for the wickedness of their doings I will drive them out of mine house, I will love them no more*: all their princes are revolters.

"Render unto Caesar that which is Caesar's but render unto God that which is God's."

body:
That's nice.

I honestly have no beef with you, but when it comes to people trying to destroy ones culture and family, no, I have no love for them. Do I pray they change and see the error of their ways? Absolutely. I'd they did change their ways and ask forgiveness would I forgive them? Yes. If they come to kill me or my family will I stand idly by and quote scripture while they do it? At some point, probably, when God puts it upon my heart to be martyred, but until then, no. As a husband and father I am tasked with providing and protecting my family and those in my care, and so long as evil people rule and do ungodly things I will hate them with a righteous hatred, and give them no quarter if it comes to a fight.

You may do what you will, of course, and if I am in the wrong I guess I'll find out at the Bema seat, but I don't believe I am.

Enjoy the rest of your day.

parent.body:
That's nice.

I honestly have no beef with you, but when it comes to people trying to destroy ones culture and family, no, I have no love for them. Do I pray they change and see the error of their ways? Absolutely. I'd they did change their ways and ask forgiveness would I forgive them? Yes. If they come to kill me or my family will I stand idly by and quote scripture while they do it? At some point, probably, when God puts it upon my heart to be martyred, but until then, no. As a husband and father I am tasked with providing and protecting my family and those in my care, and so long as evil people rule and do ungodly things I will hate them with a righteous hatred, and give them no quarter if it comes to a fight.

You may do what you will, of course, and if I am in the wrong I guess I'll find out at the Bema seat, but I don't believe I am.

Enjoy the rest of your day.

parent.body: I actually find that issue interesting, as God is love, and if he is love, how can he hate? The answer that I have arrived at is "Perfect Hate," or otherwise not the same type of hate we're speaking about. To hate is to feel passionate dislike, and, unlike hate us humans feel, God can have a balance of dislike and love for someone without unjustly/hypocritically hating them, or will for someone to change while loving them all the same. However, we cannot have this balance of love and hate before it turns into the type of hypocritical judging that Jesus warned against in Matthew 7:1-2. God is never unjust, therefore he may judge, love, and "hate."
parent.body_html: I actually find that issue interesting, as God is love, and if he is love, how can he hate? The answer that I have arrived at is "Perfect Hate," or otherwise not the same type of hate we're speaking about. To hate is to feel passionate dislike, and, unlike hate us humans feel, God can have a balance of dislike and love for someone without unjustly/hypocritically hating them, or will for someone to change while loving them all the same. However, we cannot have this balance of love and hate before it turns into the type of hypocritical judging that Jesus warned against in Matthew 7:1-2. God is never unjust, therefore he may judge, love, and "hate."

body:
Solid point, and a trap that myself and many brothers had fallen into recently.  At the end of the day, Jesus was very clear towards the end of Matthew 5 and 6 regarding how we are to approach handling of enemies and what worry will bring us.  What good comes from getting worked up about hypothetical futures? I want what's best for my children like any other person here, but stewing in that hatred is damaging to the spirit.  This is our home only for a very short time, and history shows that sometimes persecution comes with the territory. 

"Therefore do not worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow will worry about itself. Each day has enough trouble of its own."

parent.body: Someone's entire life shouldn't be political. To replace entertainment with political hatred/negativity on one side or the other will, most likely, cause a person to hate those they disagree with because everyone else they agree with hates those same people. Of course, we need to have an impact on politics, but we must set aside time for it in a day, and not let it overcome our life. If we let politics overcome our life and identity, we will become more focused on being right on our political spectrum than being right with God.
